Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Predicting Drought Adaptation in C4 Plants with High Throughout Quantitative Phenotyping
Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER project will test whether use of a novel combination of high-throughput field-scale measurement of ion accumulation levels and carbon isotope discrimination can predict yield under stress in maize. If successful, this project will generate a new paradigm for the study of abiotic stress tolerance in maize and other C4 plants and the immediate improvement of crop abiotic stress tolerance by the plant breeding industry. It could also enable scientists to rapidly predict the consequence of genotype on adaptation to increasing temperature, decreasing water arability, and other predicted outcomes of global climate change. A postdoctoral scientist will receive training and mentorship in the integration of high throughput phenotyping, bioinformatics and quantitative genetics. All data generated in this study will be accessible through iHUB (www.ionomicshub.org) and the Purdue University Research Repository (http://purr.purdue.edu).

Many phenotypes used for drought tolerance estimation in plants are slow, costly, and of insufficient heritability to make substantial progress connecting genotype to phenotype. Measures of water relations often assess dynamic responses of the plant to the local environment, are strongly influenced by temporal factors and unusable for genetics. The absence of high throughput quantitative phenotyping approaches (e.g. phenomics) that precisely report the integrative physiological status of field-grown plants is hampering the discovery of molecular mechanisms of plant adaptation. This problem is particularly notable in plants with C4 photosynthesis and has limited the discovery of the mechanisms controlling water use in these drought adaptable species and inhibited crop improvement in maize and in many target biofuel crops including sorghum and switchgrass. Preliminary data suggests a correlation between delta-13C, the ratio of stable isotopes 13C:12C, and yield under drought and the relationship between delta-13C, water relations, and photosynthetic capacity in C4 plants. This EAGER project will test the hypothesis that the combination of water-soluble element accumulation and carbon isotope ratios in mature maize kernels can predict adaptation to drought. The specific objectives include a genome-wide assessment of genetic contribution to these traits by genome-wide association study. Both traits will be assessed within an association panel of maize in the field under a managed drought environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific literature exploring maize physiology reports variable responses of plants to water limitation in terms of their differential accumulation of the two abundant natural isotopes of carbon 12C and 13C. This ability of plants to preferentially pull different isotopic forms of CO2 out of the air during the chemical conversion of this gas to sugars, called carbon isotope discrimination or δ13C, is known to correlate with water-use-efficiency in plants that use the C3 carbon fixation pathway. Some controversy about the cause of δ13C in plants that use a C4 carbon fixation pathway, such as maize, and the response of δ13C to drought exists. If the degree of δ13C in the stored carbon in seeds can be used to predict the response of maize of to water limitation, it represents an untapped avenue to improve this crop for less resource intensive farming, better understand carbon fixation, and potentially retrospectively phenotype the seeds in germplasm collections to predict plant performance in harsh environments. Based on a strong reported relationship between δ13C and yield under drought, photosynthetic capacity, and bundle sheath leakage we tested whether δ13C was variable in maize seeds from a genetically distinct panel of 299 lines. We detected substantial genetic variation and found that more than 60% of the variation in this phenotype was due to genetics. We further explored this diversity to determine whether the variation in δ13C in the carbon accumulated by seeds across a contrast of watering regimes could predict transpiration efficiency, as estimated from the accumulation of elements. We grew the 299 maize lines in two different watering regimes, one with sufficient water and one that introduced moderate drought stress, and phenotyped their seeds for Carbon and Nitrogen isotope accumulations as well as the levels of 20 elements. We found a remarkable heritability of δ13C within environments, and a strong correlation of δ13C between seeds from sufficiently watered and drought stressed plants. Strong between-environment correlations were identified for all traits, except the poorly measured element Selenium. Strong correlations between the elements, between traits within environments and across environments were also observed. However, the only seed elemental component that remained correlated with carbon isotopes in both well-watered and water-limited conditions was Sr. Remarkably, both Ca and its chemical analog Sr accumulations in irrigated conditions were correlated with δ13C from both watered and stressed conditions. The elements Ca, Sr, Rb, and Mo were all weakly but significantly correlated with δ13C in well-watered conditions. The deviation in δ13C effect across the two watering treatments did not prove more correlated with ions and only Ni accumulation from both watered and stressed treatments, were correlated with the reaction of δ13C to water limitation.  Different genetic backgrounds’ δ13C reacted in opposing directions following water limitation. The evaluation of a large set of lines across a common environmental contrast identified this genetic dependence of response of δ13C to water limitation in maize and resolves some of the controversy in the δ13C literature studying C4 grasses.


A framework for multiple-trait, particularly correlated traits, quantitative genetics trait analysis for genotype by environment interactions was lacking and we explored multiple approaches for integrating data from multiple environments. We explored using trait co-variation in line-cross QTL and GWAS studies and dealing with correlated phenotypes across multiple environments. This led to three published and two additional manuscripts in revision, so far. Principal components analysis was effective at both extracting summary traits that reproduced the genetic determinants of large effects on single elements, and at detecting genetic loci responsible for element homeostasis that were invisible when single traits were used in genetic mapping. Despite the heritability of δ13C in our maize diversity population, and the relative stability of the trait across environments, no alleles affecting this variation were detected by Genome wide association studies, after correcting for multiple tests. The association data did point to biological mechanisms affecting the variation, when analyzed in connection with gene function predictions and gene expression data. The tests for allele effects on δ13C were more significant, on average, for the genes encoding the reactions of photosynthesis than for the average gene. This indicates that variation in the enzymes catalyzing the reactions of photosynthesis contribute to δ13C in maize. Remarkably, even better performance was recorded for genes that are were identified as expressed in bundle sheath mesophyll, indicating that plant functions which take place in this tissue, and for which we do not have established gene annotation categories (e.g. bundle sheath leakage) may have greater impacts. More work is expected to be published as the data are further mined by our and other laboratories.
